Lesson Narrative

By now, students have seen how the parameters of a quadratic expression in standard form and in factored form relate to the graph representing the function. In the past few lessons, students worked with decontextualized quadratic functions. In this lesson, they transfer what they learned about the graphs to make sense of quadratic functions that model concrete contexts.

Students interpret equations and graphs of quadratic functions in terms of the situations they represent. They use their analyses to solve problems and to compare quadratic functions given in different representations. Along the way, they practice reasoning quantitatively and abstractly.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Interpret (orally and in writing) the graph and equation representing a function in terms of the context.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Explain how a quadratic equation and its graph relate to a situation.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including x-intercept, y-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 7.14.1: Evaluating Quadratic Functions in the Real World
  • 7.14.2: Interpreting a Functional Relationship Between Two Quantities
    • 7.14.2: Self Check
    • 7.14.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.14.3: Analyzing Functions Using Different Representations
    • 7.14.3: Self Check
    • 7.14.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.14.4: Using Quadratic Functions to Solve Problems
  • 7.14.5: Identifying Key Features of Graphed Functions

Students will also complete a series of problems in 7.14.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Graphing technology
  • Pre-printed cards, cut from copies of the blackline master
  • Scientific calculators

Required Preparation

Acquire devices that can run Desmos (recommended) or other graphing technology. It is ideal if each student has their own device.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • \(y\)-intercept
  • vertex
  • quadratic function
  • maximum
  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their proactivity.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • All Together Now
  • Guided Mastery

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Proactivity from Character Lab.
